content: frankie s knitted stuff starburst this pattern uses the mosaic crochet technique and lots of bright colours to make a blanket that really does look like stained glass the squares are much simpler to work than they look and the whole thing is a lot of fun to make i thoroughly enjoyed every stage of this particular project what is mosaic crochet good question - i had trouble finding out much about this technique although there are some lovely blankets out there that inspired me basically it s a combination of double_crochet stitches us single crochet worked into the back of the stitch from the previous round and trebles us double_crochet which are worked into the front of the stitch two rounds below this combined with sharply contrasting colours allows you to create complex patterns with colours that cross rounds while only ever using one colour at a time you change colour each round alternating black with bright colours and the pattern only starts to appear after you have worked several rounds don t worry if this doesn t leave you any the wiser i ll take you through each round of the square until you ve got the hang of it the colours the choice of colours is crucial for this pattern there are seven brightly coloured rounds in each of my starburst squares and you could use a different colour for each or just three per square as i have done the only non-negotiable is the black for this technique to work you need a strong dark colour as the contrast don t be tempted to replace the black with white for example i tried that and it was a disaster so … in an attempt to avoid too many ends to darn in while still sticking to my love of rainbow colours i came up with a way of using small amounts of lots of bright colours while still only having eight ends to darn in at the end of each square i also worked out how to arrange the colours so that the same amount of each was used this had the added benefit of making each of the 42 squares in the blanket unique i chose 21 shades of stylecraft special dk 295 m / 100g and rolled little balls of about 20g of each in fact i ended up using about 12g of each colour this gave me three shades for each of the seven colours of the rainbow roughly speaking - my violets are really pinks for example winding the colours into small balls made this project much more portable i also made myself a simple shade card with samples of the colours in order i used this as my reference throughout the project and would recommend that you make one too obviously you may well have leftover yarn to use but should you want to use the same colours as me i ve listed them on the next page 2 red bright
